extracted-table.table-caption: Distribution of stimulus modalities across the naturalistic corpus
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Note. Paradigms engaged auditory, visual, and tactile sensory modalities, both separately and in combination.

caption.p: Distribution of stimulus modalities across the naturalistic corpus

fn.p: Note. Paradigms engaged auditory, visual, and tactile sensory modalities, both separately and in combination.

extracted-table.transformed-table:
Table 1.
Distribution of stimulus modalities across the naturalistic corpus
Stimulus modalityNumber of experiments
Auditory50 (13%)
Audiovisual154 (41%)
Visual150 (40%)
Visual + tactile (pain)9 (2%)
Visual + tactile5 (1%)
Tactile4 (1%)Note. Paradigms engaged auditory, visual, and tactile sensory modalities, both separately and in combination.

extracted-table.table-caption: Distribution of stimulus types across the naturalistic corpus
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Note. Within each stimulus modality, multiple types of experimental stimuli were included across the dataset.

caption.p: Distribution of stimulus types across the naturalistic corpus

fn.p: Note. Within each stimulus modality, multiple types of experimental stimuli were included across the dataset.

extracted-table.transformed-table:
Table 2.
Distribution of stimulus types across the naturalistic corpus
Stimulus typeNumber of experiments
Film169 (45%)
Virtual reality121 (32%)
Speech32 (9%)
Music21 (6%)
Video game13 (4%)
3D image6 (2%)
Tactile6 (2%)
Picture4 (1%)
Sounds1 (<1%)Note. Within each stimulus modality, multiple types of experimental stimuli were included across the dataset.

extracted-table.table-caption: Manual functional decoding results across meta-analytic groupings
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Note. The relative contributions of each manually derived metadata term (e.g., term frequencies) were computed for all MAGs, controlling for the base rate by dividing each term’s per-MAG count by that term’s total count across the corpus. Base rates are provided as the total count for each term.*Significant forward inference at pcorrected < 0.05.†Significant reverse inference at pcorrected < 0.05 (corrected for false discovery rate).

caption.p: Manual functional decoding results across meta-analytic groupings

fn.p: Note. The relative contributions of each manually derived metadata term (e.g., term frequencies) were computed for all MAGs, controlling for the base rate by dividing each term’s per-MAG count by that term’s total count across the corpus. Base rates are provided as the total count for each term.
Significant reverse inference at pcorrected < 0.05 (corrected for false discovery rate).

extracted-table.table-caption: Automated functional decoding results from Neurosynth
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Note. The top ten Neurosynth (NS) terms are provided for each MAG, along with the corresponding Pearson’s correlation coefficient (corr.) that indicates the strength of similarity between Neurosynth maps and each MAG.
